fact_list.fact_text: In the daytime whenever visibility is poor or if it is raining, switch on your headlights.
Switching on your headlights will not affect your fuel consumption.
It is advisable when parking in unlit or poorly lit roads at night to leave your side or parking lights on.
Try not to look directly at the headlights of oncoming vehicles but direct your vision slightly to the left.
Always keep a look-out for flashes from the brake lights of vehicles in front.

When approaching a curve or intersection with poor visibility, it is a good idea to flash your headlights to let pedestrians and oncoming cyclists and motorists know that you are heading into the curve or intersection.
It is unsafe to drive with the interior lights on as they reduce your external visibility.
Motorcyclists are required to switch on their headlights throughout the day.
Alcohol, even in small quantities, makes you less safe on the roads.
The safe rule is: If you drink, don’t drive.
The same applies to drugs even when taken medicinally.
The prescribed legal limit for blood alcohol content is 80 milligrams of alcohol per 100 milliliters of blood, while for breath, it is 35 micrograms of alcohol per 100 milliliters of breath.
Any person caught driving with blood or breath alcohol content exceeding the prescribed limit will be charged in court for drink driving.

A person can be charged for drink driving even when the blood or breath alcohol content is below the legal limit if there is evidence to show that they were unable to control the vehicle due to alcoholic intoxication.
The penalty for drink driving is a fine between $1,000 and $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 6 months.
There is also a mandatory 1-year disqualification of the offender’s driving license for drink driving.
A repeat offender will face a mandatory jail sentence not exceeding 1 year for drink driving.
All lorries used for carrying workers on the carriage deck must be fitted with canopies and higher side railings.
The load on any vehicle on a road should always be securely fastened.
The front passenger seat(s) in the lorry’s cabin must be occupied before workers can be carried on the rear carriage deck.

Lorry owners who wish to use their lorries to carry workers must display a Maximum Passenger Capacity (MPC) label on the right side of the lorry’s rear tailboard, indicating the maximum number of workers that can be transported when the carriage deck is empty.

For safety, when workers are carried in lorries, they should be made to sit down properly, and the maximum allowable height of a seated worker shall not exceed 1.1 meters measured from the carriage deck.
The vehicle must not carry an excess number of workers based on the minimum deck space requirement of 0.372 square meters per seated worker.
When goods or equipment are transported along with workers, the number of workers carried should be reduced according to the remaining available floor area.
When transporting workers on the carriage deck, the vehicle must not travel faster than the posted road speed limit or the vehicle speed limit of 60 km/h, whichever is lower.
Anyone who drives a vehicle with an overall height exceeding 4.5 meters without police escort is committing an offence.
